title: #1 on my list
review: The photo shows the seaweed brands I've tried in order of preference.Jayone: crisp and lightly salted. Delicious at a bargain price. These are great with a meal or just to satisfy those evening cravings. I also cut them up and take them to the theatre in place of popcorn. These are a tiny bit saltier than the gimMe brand.gimMe: very similar if not quite as salty as the Jayone, just a little more expensive and slightly more oil. They seem to flake a little more than the Jayone, but are still very good. I do like having the option to buy 10g trays or 5g trays for taking along as a snack or addition to a meal.Black Label Gourmet: driest and least salty of the bunch, but still a nice crunch. A little different flavor because they're roasted with olive oil instead of sesame or sunflower. They taste a little less sea-like and a little more earthy. These are the ones I like to use to roll salmon or tuna.Wickedly Prime: I can't recommend these at all. Though they supposedly have less salt than a couple of the other brands, they are terribly greasy and taste so salty I couldn't eat them; neither could my family. The only thing I can think to do with them is rinse them and re-roast them to see if they improve. Definitely not worth buying.
author: Elisa S.

title: The BEST seasoned seaweed makers in the WORLD
review: I ate the entire box in a week. This stuff is DELICIOUS. If you enjoy traditional Korean seaweed, this is it, folks. I've tried several American made brands and they all use WAY too much oil or the seaweed is too thick. This seaweed is perfectly thin and crumbly, salted and lightly seasoned with oils. The pouches arrived the original 24 pack box that was inside an amazon box. I appreciated the Amazon box as I don't want someone to see I have delicious seaweed and decide to take it. I felt like the snack packs had a generous amount of seaweed in them, compared to other snack packs I've tried. One pouch would definitely be great for a rice bowl, udon or just in between classes. Mmm so good.

title: A lot of seaweed for the price!
review: I bought this seaweed as a snack food not for sushi, so I can't answer any questions or have any input towards it's position in sushi or rice. I eat it like I'd eat potato chips.I don't think I understood how much seaweed I was getting for the price. I've neever had seaweed and I've never bought it in person so I had no expectations. The massive box showed up filled with a ton of snack pack sized seaweed crisps. My initial taste test of it was not great since I didn't like it too much but it eventually grew on me. If you're new to it or you're feeding it to kids, it takes a couple of tries to know if you like it or not. The packages are easy to open, just tear them like any other snacckfood, and take out the little tray full of sheets.The sheets are a little greasy from whatever processing happens, this isn't an issue at all but I figured I'd mention it. A friend of mine that eats similar products more reguarly figured they needed more salt but they are clearly labeled "Lightly salted". Avoid the moisture absorber at the bottom of each pack and you're good to go. This tasty snack will stick in your teeth and affect breath so rinsing your mouth out after eating would be advisable.Pros: Tons of seaweed for the price, Good quality and healthy snack, easy to open.Cons: Slightly greasy, can affect breath/teeth
author: Liam Theis

title: Good size snack and very healthy.
review: As someone who has never tried seaweed before these took a minute to get used to. They are thin sheets of dried seaweed in a little plastic tray, in single serving packs. There's a bit of a waste of packaging but I guess there isn't another way to do it without breaking them up. They are kind of fragile. The serving size is generous and very few calories. I got used to the taste by the 2nd or 3rd sheet. It's a little spinachy, that's probably the closest thing I can think of in taste. Not strong though. They aren't terribly filling but they take some time to eat and make for a good snack.

title: Rosemary Oleoresin as an ingredient - be careful
review: I was very hopeful this snack would be wonderful. I liked them. Not terrific, but sort of what is expected when you combine seaweed, salt, rice crackers, and sugar. My objection is about 20 minutes after having a handful I was very hot. And I recalled how there is an odd aftertaste, reminiscent of MSG on the tongue. I checked the ingredients. No MSG. But it does list Rosemary Oleoresin. I Googled this additive and found this: Rosemary Oleoresin is a circulatory and nerve stimulant. Interesting. I definitely did not like the hot flushed sensations and won't be buying this again.
author: Elizabeth Miller

title: I didn't think I would like it.  Quickly acquired taste.
review: I am addicted to this stuff even though I thought I was crazy for buying it. Then it gets slightly chewy like beef jerky.  Then out of no where, the sheet disappears.  Ha!  I love how it only has one carb per package.  I usually eat 2-3 packages per sitting.  I need to look for a version that has larger servings.

title: 25 calories per packet, good price
review: These make wonderful snacks especially if you’re craving a little salt as they are a bit salty.  You might find yourself drinking more beer or other beverages while eating these.  (Just like when you eat pretzels or chips at a bar).  The size is perfect for a box or bag lunch but I always wish I had more sheets of nori (the seaweed) once I reach the bottom of the packet.  They’re addictive!  At 25 calories and a single serving per package, it seems that it’s be a good food to eat during a diet.  The inner clear container is recyclable (I can see the recycling symbol on it but can’t read what type of plastic it is.  I think it may be in Asian letters). I like to keep a couple in my car for snacks on-the-go.  At 62 cents a package, it’s at least half the price I’d pay at the grocery store and that’s when it’s on sale.

title: Good with nut/seed butter
review: I've tried the GimMe roasted seaweed flavors sea salt, olive oil, sesame oil, and teriyaki and like them all. I had tried another brand years ago and didn't like it, so I was dubious about any "fishy" taste even though I know it's fish that taste like algae (which seaweed is) and not really the reverse... Apparently this brand is mild enough for me.I like to eat them with a little bit of nut or seed butter, with the nori sheets rolled up or folded over or covered with another sheet like a sandwich. I usually eat 2 to 4 small sheets at a time. The remainder in the pack stays fresh if I just put the plastic tray in a sandwich bag and seal with a clothes pin. But I have to keep this bag in a rodent-proof container because apparently a little visitor from the crawlspace thought they were delicious... just a plastic bag was not enough protection!

title: I love Gimme Teriyaki flavor! A review great for those paying close attention to sodium/nutrition
review: Let me start by saying I LOVE Seaweed snacks. If you're someone who has never tried seaweed snacks before, I would start with Gimme brand Teriyaki flavor to introduce you to it!! This product tastes amazing, and doesn't taste overly greasy/oily like other seaweed snack brands sometimes do. This review is specifically for people watching their sodium intake/are on a sodium restriction/are interesting in hearing my perspective on this brand.I am a Registered Dietitian and often pay close attention to what I chose for myself so that I can better make recommendations for friends/family/clients, and I love that one pack (0.17oz) has 30mg of sodium (salt) and is such a nice healthy delicious snack! For anyone who is put on a low salt diet, depending on what your restriction is (again disclaimer, first check with your doctor and RD) you can comfortably have 3 of these 0.17oz packs, and still be eating less than 100mg of salt.  Something to always look for when checking nutrition facts of snacks is whether or not the information you see in the nutrition label is for the whole container, or if it has multiple servings (in which you would want to multiply whatever you see in the label by the number of servings).I have seen other seaweed snack brands have up to 500mg of sodium or more per seaweed pack which is so insane!! Personally, I am very sensitive to salt so other brands with lots of sodium usually cause me to wake up feeling so swollen, but the Gimme Teriyaki flavor is much lower in salt than other brands so I can relax knowing that if I'm craving it I can relax knowing a few packs won't bother me! I love it! Definitely recommend!Note: The other Gimme Seaweed snack flavors, Sesame Flavor and the Sea Salt, have 65mg per the same 0.17oz bags (still not bad). Still not bad, but I probably would not recommend more than about two 0.17 oz packs for the Sesame and Sea Salt flavors for someone on a strict sodium restriction from their doctor. However, just be careful because the larger 0.35oz size bags for both flavors have 130mg for a whole pack (they mention that they have 65mg per serving with 2 servings).Overall, I think that the Gimme Teriyaki flavor is a great choice given that it is only 30mg sodium per pack compared to 65mg salt per pack of the other flavors, and that even for the larger 0.35 oz of the Teriyaki packs they only have 60 mg salt for the whole pack compared to 130mg per 0.35oz pack of the Sesame and Sea Salt flavors.
author: Jaimie L.

title: DELICIOUS AND ADDICTIVE
review: My friend offered me some of these when I was visiting her house and I looked at her like she was crazy. You just eat slices of seaweed by itself? What's wrong with you? It's good, she assured me. Well, I do like sushi, so I hesitantly agreed to try her weird seaweed in a plastic box snack. How can I put into words the feelings that overtook me when my tongue first encountered the papery goodness of these seaweed snacks? How do I describe the exquisite blend of seasonings that tickled my tastebuds into an all out joygasm? These things are like crack and I am an addict. They taste as good as pure, uncut blow. I ate six packets yesterday and ordered more. This is where all my money will go from now on. Rent? Electricity? Who needs that when you can spend your entire pay check on thin slices of seaweed grilled and seasoned to perfection? I hope whoever runs this company enjoys getting filthy rich off me until I hit rock bottom and check into seaweed rehab.

title: I LOVE seaweed snacks
review: I LOVE seaweed snacks. I have tried several brands and this one is so far my favourite! I have only tried the Wasabi flavour, and I won't be changing that for a while! These are very fresh and flavourful, unlike others where you can barely feel any seasoning. If you like putting wasabi on your sushi then you will surely like the taste of this. It has that slightly spicy/slightly sweet blend, and it's salty too. Whenever I'm craving a snack or something crispy to munch on, these are the healthiest and lowest calories snacks I can think of that satisfy that snack urge and actually fills you up for a while. At first the little singular packet might look small (there's about 20 slices of seaweed in each packet) but it keeps me full for a couple of hours. Highly recommend if you like the taste of sushi!

title: So tasty and healthy, too!

It's reasonably cheap when you buy it in bulk, and even more so if you do a monthly subscription like we do. But it's the subtle sesame flavor--from sesame oil rather than seeds--that makes this seaweed snack stand out among the many other tasty versions out there. Highly recommended.

title: Hotter than other brands.  Delicious!
review: I love the taste of seaweed and wasabi, and have an unsatisfiable love for spicy foods.  I have had other brands of wasabi seaweed snacks, and these are by FAR the spiciest.  I saw someone mention that the spice is variable, so it's possible I've eaten extra spicy packs, I suppose, but these have enough kick to "clear your sinuses".  If you like your spicy food no hotter than "medium" you will probably find these too spicy.  If you love hot foods, you'll probably be pleased that these are hotter than most "hot" chips (including potato chips) you've tried.  These are also less greasy than other brands of seaweed snacks.I love them.  Seaweed isn't for anyone as people mentioned.  Sure it tastes fishy.  Do you like the tase of the seaweed in sushi?  If you haven't tried sushi, then this might not be the best intro to seaweed.  If you have had sushi and you particularly like or dislike the seaweed taste there, that should predict pretty well whether you'll like these.  For me, these easily remind me of the taste of sushi with wasabi.I love these and will be buying more.
author: Emily

title: Go-to snack
review: I ordered some of these Annie Chun's Seaweed Snacks after watching a friend much on roasted seaweed.  After searching on amazon, I chose these and two flavors from Sea's Gift.  I chose the Roasted Sesame flavor over the other flavors because the ingredients are simpler.  Each package has small (but not tiny) rectangles of seaweed lined up on a tray.  I fold the pieces in half and stuff them in my mouth.  I find that if I bite the seaweed, I get more "crumbs."  Either way, I still wind up with pieces of seaweed on my shirt and have to check myself in the mirror after eating (also pieces get stuck in my teeth like spinach, so I have learned to check that, too). I like the texture of this seaweed-paper thin, light, and crisp.  I like the flavor-mild.  I prefer this brand to Sea's Gift because of the milder flavor.  They seem fresh.  I did not detect any off-tastes or rancidity.  I appreciate the high vitamin content and the low calories.  I reach for these when I want something crunchy.  I eat them as a snack in between meals to keep me from eating crackers. I also eat them along side a meal instead of crackers.

title: Best snack ever!
review: I must admit I did not like these AT ALL when I forced myself to eat the first pack. I finally decided to try them one more time, took a few bites and low and behold...delicious!  My teenager loves them also so we are making sure to keep a good supply on hand so we can snack on these in the evening instead of reaching for unhealthy chips.  I actually haven't bought a bag of chips since buying these and we used to go through a couple of big bags of chips and dip a week. They are salty (which is what I crave) but not overly so.  Crispy and savory...and healthy too! Can't beat it!UPDATE: NOVEMBER12, 2013I have ordered several more times and we still love these.  I actually crave them now! title: Love this stuff
review: I find it strange that I even like this product, as I don't like to eat sushi. I even avoid using fish sauce as an ingredient when Asian recipes call for it bc it grosses me out.  Yet this I like. It's stinky at first, yes, LOL, but in a weirdly good way I suppose.  I am dieting for some months now and finding anything to snack on without racking up the calories is hard work, so when I do snack, I need guilt-free and low-caloric snacks.  I eat 10 or so at a time but it's hard to stop and I want them to last.  Now with this package of 12, I am golden.  I tried the other varieties of this brand, but didn't like it at all. It is obviously the 'hot kick" that this one gives that makes it more interesting to me. It comes well packed and the 'best before' date is April of 2014, almost six months from now. They won't last that long :)

title: Delicious, and no wheat!
review: This product has a few simple ingredients and delivers great flavor without the MSG you often find in other seasoned seaweed products. It's also free of soy sauce, which usually contains wheat, so it suits my gluten free diet.  I drink soy milk and take a supplement with soy isoflavones which tend to bind iodine, so the super boost of iodine in the seaweed is a great benefit for me.The seaweed sheets are crisp and we eat them like potato chips or sometimes we wrap them around warm rice. Make sure you have a napkin. The healthy oils on this seaweed can be a little messy on the hands.My kids love this stuff. - They were introduced to seaweed at a young age. I have to fight them for my share.

title: A good snack item.
review: Seaweed snacks aren't so common in America yet, but you find them a lot in Asian grocery stores. What are they like? Well, they're crispy and salty snacks, that pretty much melt away as you eat them, a good match for beer, I'd say. They aren't very filling though, so don't plan on making a meal out of them. Annie Chun's version of this snack is the one I usually get. The roasted sesame flavor is something agreeable to most American palettes, although their wasabi flavored snacks are also good.A note about storage: Once you open these, you want to make sure they're consumed pretty quickly or stored in a dry place. They don't stay crisp long once open, especially if it's humid.

title: chips of the sea
review: I love these seaweed snacks.  Each bite starts out crispy, with just the right amount of salt and sesame flavor, and then turns chewy (but not the kind of chewy thicker seaweed can be where it seems to expand in your mouth as you chew it).  I can eat an entire package without feeling remorse; the caloric and sodium levels are not high.  This is a healthful alternative to eating potato chips and seems to satisfy me just as much.  My supervisor likes these with smoked salmon spread. Sounds good, but I have not tried it yet. I have a coworker who does not like seaweed.  I convinced her to try these, because they are so light and yummy (to me), but these were no exception for her.  She sounded like a cat trying to clear a hairball.  So, clearly these will not suit everyone's taste.  I am receiving these seaweed snacks through subscription ordering - very convenient.

title: Delicious Ocean Leaves For Your Munching Pleasure! (or at lease for my wife's...)
review: It pains me to write this because I personally despise all edibles from the briny, or otherwise fresh, natural bodies of water that make up the majority of our shared living sphere, Earth.  However, as my wife and I share this account, I am compelled to wax eloquently on her behalf in regards to the alleged deliciousness of Annie Chun's Seaweed Snacks, Roasted Wasabi, 0.35-Ounce Packages (Pack of 12).  While the smell of an open container of these crumble sea crisps is enough to make me hurl like a sailing student in a sea storm (a bit of an exaggeration), they seem to consistently please the misses, who has described them as "spicy" and "yummy."  Additionally pleasing to her is the ability to subscribe and save and leave open containers on the coffee table to torture yours truly.  Sea snackers, please eat responsibly.

title: LOVE 'EM - JUST TOO EXPENSIVE
review: My wife and I love these and we had these on subscription, but they just got to be too expensive. Then we found similar snacks at one of the local Asian Grocery stores. They had products from several manufacturers, so we tried a bunch. They ALL basically tasted the same, so we now just buy the ones that are on sale. They are under $4.00 for 8 pack and 10 pack units (depending on the brand). THIS IS MUCH CHEAPER THAN THE PRICE OF THESE ON AMAZON. Since we eat these all the time, this is much more economical for us. My wife hates the "fresh" taste of fish, but she loves these, so I am surprised that people found them too "fishy".

title: The Perfect Snack for us
review: I have to admit, before I opened up the Seaweed Snacks, I was expecting a thicker snack because of the picture on the box. When I saw the actual product...I thought...* Wow!...They are sooo thin!.. *Will they have flavor?..*Would they be filling?...  *Will we munch half the boxes up in one sitting trying to feel like we ate something?, and *Did I waste my money?*... Our answer: Definitely NOT wasted money! To our suprise, yesterday, my husband and I shared one .35 oz. pkg, which, with a drink, and found that not only was our serving of the "wafers" filling enough to take our hunger away until dinner, but was also very tasty!...(Actually, it was so tasty that today, I ate a whole pkg myself!... They're sooo addicting!!!). The seaweed flavor is strong enough for its taste to come through, but yet, subtle enough to not overwhelm the tastebuds...Yummy!! My husband and I liked the snack so much, I told two of our neighbors about them and let them try some. They also liked them alot, so I gave them each a pkg. to take with them. We even broke the snack into little pieces and let my neighbors' 6 mos. baby suck on them until soft, (when put in the mouth, the hard *wafer* texture  almost immediately  dissolves into the texture of cooked spinach). Once softened she ate about 3 wafers right down!  (If you do let your young child try it..I would strongly recommend an adult breaking, holding, and feeding the small wafer pieces on his/her fingers for the child.) My neighbor said to her husband, *She, (the baby), loves them, too...We have to buy some!*I'm  glad I've found this snack, as being Seaweed, it has soo many more nutritional benefits,(necessary vitamins and minerals, and being low in fat), that I believe it is a great alternative to many of the other snacks that are being sold. It does, however, have a little more salt on it than I would like...(health wise).  It would be nice if they came out with a low,(or at least a lower salt), seaweed snack package...but even if they dont..I will continue to buy these due to their delicious flavor!Anyway, to summarize it all we decided that  [[ASIN:B003NUYBV8 Annie Chun's Seaweed Snacks, Roasted Sesame, 0.35-Ounce Packages (Pack of 12)] will be the Perfect Snack for us and would definitely recommend them!  Sarah

title: If you like dried seaweed and savoury/salty, these snacks are for you.
review: If you like seaweed and tend toward savoury / salty snacks, then these are delicious. They look like pieces of "green" paper, each about the size of a Post-It Note. Good for a (very) light snack, especially if you want to avoid the caloric issues of chips and so on.There are "2 servings" per container - a serving" is about 9 sheets. If you choose to ziplock the leftovers, keep the little silica bag that comes inside (to keep them crisp, or they can turn a little rubbery, depending on how many days you keep them before eating). Kept unopened in their original packaging, they'll keep for ages.

title: Great for people who don't like seaweed
review: Don't get me wrong, this snack does tastes like the seaweed it is.  BUT of all the seaweed snacks I've tried, and I've tried half a dozen at my local health food store, THIS is the one I decided to buy in bulk as a subscription on Amazon (FYI: I spend a fortune at that local health food store, so don't feel too sorry for it, and I have to strike a balance on spending somewhere!).  What makes this snack better than the others?  Three things: 1) the seaweed is in small sheets and is much thinner -- you don't get a big thick layer of it, 2) it has a great distracting hot & salty taste (salt & wasabi) that gives it a refreshing zing, and 3) it has nice crispiness.  I eat sea vegetables for general health (anti-cancer, etc.) and thyroid health.  A few sheets of these a day and I'm good.  For the first time  (not counting sushi) it's easy to eat my seaweed.

title: Seaweed snacks, Wasabi flavor
review: Be aware that these are the type of thing you probably either really like or really don't like, and if you don't care for sushi you probably won't like these. Yes, that sounds like a "Duh" statement, but they really are sort of fishy. Crispy texture, and a nice little wasabi kick, but don't let them sit on your tongue too long or they sort of melt and taste very seaweedy. My husband spit out his one and only taste, but I thought they were pretty good. On the other hand, a co-worker actually gagged and wiped her tongue after one bite. Very crunchy and thin, but a little bit goes a long way for me. I don't think I'll order them again simply because I'd eat them occasionally but not as my first choice for a snack. I do like the wasabi tingle, but I'll stick to wasabi peas.

title: Weird at first but good
review: Completely different from anything I've ever had before. My first impression of these seaweed snacks was "salted cellophane," but then I gave it a moment, tried another, and another.They're very mild in taste. Like paper thin greens kissed with salt, that start out crunchy and completely soften in your mouth. I tried a single pack bought elsewhere and liked it enough to come back here for the case. They're tasty, but messy. If they were a a little narrower, you could more easily fit a whole one in your mouth and eat neatly. And they tend to disintegrate and stick to your teeth so I wouldn't eat these at work, but at home with dinner, or as a snack, sure, no problem.Snackable vegetables, seriously. While they're not particularly filling, they're kind of fun to eat and are supposed to be pretty good for you. High in vit. A and 30 calories for half a package. (20 calories fat of the 30, from the oil)I ate these 3-4 sheets at a time and stored the open package in the fridge. They stayed crunchy until I finished the package, which took me about 3 days.

title: Inconsistent Taste
review: I first tasted Annie Chun's seaweed three years ago while in California. It was delicious, especially the Wasabi, so I purchased about ten packs. After returning home, I found it could be ordered from Amazon at a very reasonable price and have purchased them regularly ever since. NO MORE! The last shipment contained a few packages that did not smell right. The pieces of seaweed had a dull, grey coating on them. They tasted terrible. I blew it off the first couple of times and went ahead with another shipment. Last night I opened a container that smelled of burning plastic. The pieces were once again dull and appeared to have a grey coating on them. The coating, unfortunately, was not wasabi. It is strange that not all of the packages have the smell or coating on them, but now I am uncomfortable eating the product. I trusted Annie Chun's product but have decided to stop purchasing it, going with my intuition that there is a problem at the source they are not addressing.

title: Greasy & salty & unflling
review: I ordered these because I thought they'd be a great snack when kayaking. A lot of bulky packaging. I had no idea what to expect. These are oily to the touch, bland and salty. (Yes, I know seaweed is salty) but the flavor was just oily salt. I'm not a potato chip person, so maybe if you're a chip-person, these may appeal to you a bit more. I had to use a lot of hand sanitizer to degrease my hands afterwards. (Don't carry napkins in yak) I'll be eating them elsewhere with some chipolte powder.Interestingly, no fiber in these, so it wasn't filling at all. Kinda pointless. Not a lot of calories, but not enough nutritional bang.And a warning - plan on brushing your teeth afterwards - had pieces stuck in my teeth the rest of the day.

title: Mmmm.  Fishy paper slime!
review: I found these to be completely disappointing.  I was looking for a healthy, low-carb snack with crunch.  The description/reviews seemed to imply that's what these were.  I was thinking they'd be like kale chips, and I've also had seaweed based snacks that I enjoyed in the past, so I rolled the dice.  I'm a pretty adventurous eater, so why not?  When the box arrived (unfortunately, I'm stuck with 12 packages of these now), I opened the first package and reached in-- what I pulled out was as thin as the thinnest paper (translucent, in fact), and flexible-- when bent in half, they tear a little but do not 'snap.'  There went my hopes of a satisfying crunch.  Still, I ate one.  It tasted like fish, not sesame, and the texture became slimy as I chewed.  In fact, they get nice and wedged into the crevasses of your molars like toffee, so you get to enjoy that fishy taste for a while!  I ate one more "crisp" just to be sure I hadn't gotten a bad one... and... yep.  I can't face a third one, even for science.  These were not enjoyable and I suspect I will be hard-pressed to find them a good home.
author: Tree

title: Delicious, crispy - an unusual snack
review: These seaweed snacks were an impulse item, and I'm so glad we tried them.  There are 12 individually sealed packages in the box, and each package has about 20 super-thin seaweed snacks.  They're almost thin enough to read through, and the whole container only has 2 carbs, making them perfect for low-carb dieters.  They're surprisingly filling, and not overly salty.  They are extremely crispy and the entire package should be eaten soon after opening.  Humidity will make them gummy in just a short time.The nutrition information from Annie Chun's website says that each package of this sesame flavor has: 60 calories, 2 grams protein, 140 mg sodium, 5 grams of fat, 70% of daily vitamin A, 12% of daily vitamin C, and minerals (unnamed on the ingredients list).I like that these are all-natural and don't contain preservatives or food coloring.  I like that it's a novel way to eat vegetables, and that my kids love them. Next we'll try the wasabi flavor.My only complaint about this product is that they use canola oil in them.  Canola oil is in so many foods we eat, and the process used to make it (hexane - a petroleum product, and high heat) causes it to produce free radicals in our body.  Free radicals are linked to obesity, heart disease and degenerative diseases in our bodies.  I would much prefer that all foods be made with cold-pressed oils like olive, peanut or sunflower oil.But canola oil aside, these seaweed snacks are delicious, filling, low carb, and we'll be buying them again.

title: Two words...Not good!
review: There are so many other things you could eat instead of these "snacks" to feel healthy and proactive about your health.  I was really excited to try these after reading some of the reviews.  I like unique flavors, seaweed and wasabi included.  These see through, tissue paper thin wisps are perhaps the worst thing I have ever eaten.  Granted I've never tried water used to clean fish guts which has been sitting out in the hot sun for three days but I imagine if I were to drink this water, it would taste like these snacks.  At best, there is a hint of wasabi which is so short lived there is no way to mask the awful taste.  Find something else to snack on, anything, you'll be very glad you did.Now I just have to find some kind of craft project to do with ALL these little tiny sheets of seaweed I've purchased. title: Inedible!

The wasabi flavor was not the problem - the dead fish flavor was. As a previous reviewer stated so eloquently, "Granted I've never tried water used to clean fish guts which has been sitting out in the hot sun for three days but I imagine if I were to drink this water, it would taste like these snacks."  So true - TOTALLY DISGUSTING!!!  It took brushing my teeth FIVE times to that nasty taste out of my mouth. I would rate it zero if I could & Amazon should not carry this item because it reflects poorly on them.

I had several of my co-workers try them in case it was just my taste. They all told me they tasted terrible and were surprised that I had bought them. One girl even spit her bite out into a tissue. I do not recommend these.

title: Best tasting, light crispy and clean. Not overly seaweed tasting with a nasty filmy aftertaste.
review: I've eaten a lot of seaweed snacks over the decades and Annie Chun's are by far my favorite in taste and texture. Sea Salt and Sesame flavor are fantastic, Wasabi ... not so much, way too strong on the wasabi. Oddly enough, many seaweed snacks can be overly seaweed tasting, maybe too heavy, pressed or cut too thick and often too oily. Trader Joe's has their version in large packs for a dollar, but I rarely finish a single pack as they are just too heavy and don't leave me wanting anymore, I've tried on several occasions. Nasty seaweed snacks often leave a filmy aftertaste in your mouth and the seasonings just don't taste balanced or right, especially as more longterm snack. And that's what I like about Annie Chun's, these snack are pressed thin, have a light crispy chew that breaks down easily, and don't leave your mouth with a gross lingering overwhelming aftertaste from bad seasoning or too much oil. The larger 0.35 oz packs are certainly the way to go compared to those tiny 0.16 oz which I can devour in under a few minutes. Found the larger cases on sale at my local Asian grocer and bought them out, I can easily eat three or more packages of the Sesame or Sea Salt a day without getting burnt out on the flavor and texture. Finding these for a dollar or less is a pretty good deal as average individual packing pricing on most other brands is around $1 for the 0.16 oz. and $2 and up for the 0.35 oz. Hoping I can keep Annie Chun's seaweed snacks stocked in the home all the time.

title: Good & Bad Batches? Mine was OK.
review: Lots of negative reviews by Amazon customers, so decided to pick one up to try at...ahem...our local Walmart. Noting ingredients sunflower and sesame oils (not canola!) and "Best Before" date a reasonable 5 months hence on "4.28.2017" took one home and just now had some with Nishiki sushi style rice. As a nori lover for at least 60 years I can say that taste and texture were as good as it gets, not "fishy" as reported by others. Took off a star because IMO it was a bit too messy oily compared to others I have enjoyed.As a side note, I would be more confident purchasing food products from Amazon if shelf life expiration dates are posted. And, with sufficient negative customer reviews a product should be checked for quality. That said, I have and will continue to purchase items not available in local grocery outlets and so far practically all been satisfactory.

title: low-calorie and should appeal to people who like the taste of sesame
review: I recently had a chance to try these.  They're not my favorite thing ever, but they do have some good qualities.  First of all, a serving is only 30 calories.  Granted, they're quite thin and not very substantial.  But enough effort is involved in eating them that you at least feel like you've gone through the motions of eating a snack, and often, for me, that's enough to get rid of my mid-afternoon hunger/boredom.Taste-wise, these remind me of many other kinds of seaweed (nori that I've had with vegetarian California rolls, kombu pieces that end up in my beans, etc.).  I can really taste the sesame oil, as well.  And these are fairly salty, although one serving only has 70 mg of sodium (3% of what you should get daily).  I do not understand why so many of the negative reviewers thought these tasted like fish.  There's no fish in them -- they're vegan!  They're also quite high in vitamin A.These are not going to appeal to everyone.  If you are fond of Asian food, especially Japanese or Korean food, you will probably be a fan of these.  These do leave a bit of oil on your fingertips, by the way.They seem to be pretty shelf-stable.  I left a completely open package on my desk overnight and they tasted the same the first day (and have the same texture) as they did the second day.

title: Very good if you love wasabi flavor/bite and seaweed snacks in general
review: Only get these if you like the taste of wasabi. Although it's a bit more subtle then the wasabi that's dabbed on your sushi, you still definitely get the wasabi bite (they seem to be along the same line of the extra spicy wasabi covered peas, maybe a little bit saltier).  With subscribe and save, these packs come out to $1/pack which is quite a bit cheaper than what you spend outside Amazon (Whole Foods, Trader Joe's or supermarket) for this type of snack.  You do get quite a few sheets in each pack (20) and each one is seasoned with the perfect amount of spicy/hot wasabi and salt.  They are also nice and crunchy since they are packaged separately, and they do not seem as greasy as some other brands I've tried from the Asian markets. Although they are not greasy, one package (which contains two 10-sheet servings) has a total of 4 grams of fat (which is a little above my 3 gram target for low fat foods and unfortunately I cannot eat only half a pack.  They seem to lose their crunchiness once they're opened...that's my excuse for eating the entire pack and I'm sticking to it).

title: Good healthy snack if you like the texture of seaweed.
review: I tried these before when I saw them at Target and I had to buy more. They are a great snack when you crave something to eat, but are not that hungry. They are low in calories and rather healthy for a snack and if you are dieting eating a few of these is better than going for a full meal. I tried some Costco brand salt seaweed snacks although the Costco seaweed snacks have more in one package they do seem cheaper if that is possible for seaweed snacks and Annie Chun's were more flavorful. The wasabi flavoring is not too strong, but there is a noticeable kick to them. If you are a spicy food fanatic like me you might not notice the spice as much, but when I shared some others though they did think there was some kick to them. The price is about standard from Amazon as the seaweed snacks I got from Costco were similarly priced.

title: I really like these; they've inspired me to make my own
review: I'd been curious about seaweed snacks for quite some time.  After trying a pack of Annie Chun's Seaweed Snacks, I have to say I am a fan.  The snacks are perfect as just that -- a snack.  They have 60 calories per container so you don't have to feel bad about eating one or two containers.The seaweed is thin but has a crispy component.  There is a bit of salt but I wouldn't say that these are anywhere near as salty as a Lay's potato chip.  Initially, the smell of the seaweed seemed very strong.  I don't eat fish but that was all I could think of when eating the first few pieces.  After a while, I didn't notice the scent so much.There are two things that I don't like about this product.  The first is the amount of packaging.  The second is the use of canola oil.  To deal with both, I've started to make my own snacks.  I use nori and apply coconut oil or sesame oil and salt and place it in the oven for a bit.  For those that think these are too salty, the make your own method allows you to control the amount of oil and salt.Made in Korea.If interested in trying a single package of Annie Chun's and your grocery store does not carry the product, try iherb.com. If interested in iherb, you can use code LEK375 for a discount.

title: tastes great, expensive price

title: What's not to like about these? (...other than the addiction!)
review: Well, I suppose if you don't like spicy food, these might not be your thing. And if you don't like wonderfully tasty, crispy (and healthy!) snacks, they might not be your thing either!But I'm guessing you already passed these by if you fall into the former category, and I'm guessing not many people fit into the latter.My only complaint with these is that the wasabi coating seems to be slightly variable on them, as in I'll have one piece that's moderately hot, and then another that's really not at all. These are horribly addictive too, so it's not like I can just eat a couple of them anyways! They're fairly healthy, which makes me not feel as bad about sucking down a whole pack, but my wallet is more of a limiting factor than my appetite on buying these damn things!In short, these are tasty but moderately spicy. If you like wasabi, you'll love them. If you like seaweed (in whatever form; seaweed salad, on/around your sushi, etc), you'll love them. If you think you hate seaweed since it sounds icky, I bet you'll still love them!

title: good taste but questionable ingredients
review: These are one of the better flavored sea weed snacks, but I'm concerned about a few of the ingredients, especially near the top is canola oil - unless it's organic, it comes from the genetically modified rape seed - there is really no such thing as 'canola' oil and i'm tired of the food manufactures intimating it is a healthy oil. NOT! People need to be educated about this non-food that truly can do you harm over time.also there is modified corn starch, also if not organic than most likely GMO based - Genetically Modified Organism - as is 90% of all corn and soy derived food stuffs in this country -unless stated as organic, youre likely on the losing end. And one more ingredient - maltodextrin -if you are gluten intolerant or sensitive or just want to cut gluten out of your diet, then you don't want this grain derived sweetener.  There are other seaweed snacks that have no additives and are not processed with questionable ingredients.

title: Good, but not something I'll buy again
review: I've pretty much loved most of the Annie Chun line so I figured that I'd give the seaweed snacks a try. There's a little hint of a fishy flavor, but it's not strong enough to put me off of eating them.Overall these are decent enough to where I'll finish the rest of the bag, but I'm not thrilled enough with this to where I see myself buying more. title: Make you own!
review: These are delicious, truly, and I can't begrudge the money I've spent on them because they made me realize how tasty and healthy seaweed can be.  These days, though, I find it much healthier, more economical and friendlier on the environment to just buy nori sheets and make them myself.  Brush nori sheets (the kind you make sushi with) with toasted sesame oil, spinkle a tiny amount of salt and then toast on a baking sheet in an oven at 225 degrees for about ten minutes until crispy.  Eeeeeeeasy, cheap, you control the ingredients and less packaging wastage.  I don't know how well these would store, mainly because I always gobble them down too quickly.  Low carb, calorie, and very tasty.

title: Amazingly good!

Love the Sesame due to the saltier flavor. I acknowledge I may be odd for that but I've always been a salt fan and these are so much better than chips! title: Good for the wasabi addict
review: I bought these at the grocery store. Came to Amazon looking for a bulk buy. ;o)I didn't really know what to expect. These are very light and flaky--I wouldn't say crispy, exactly. They disintegrate as soon as they hit the moisture in your mouth, much like cotton candy does. They have a nice wasabi flavor, strong, but not so hot that it would prevent you from just downing the whole package at once. (Well, not for me anyway. But I am a bit of a wasabi addict.)That said, they are so ephemeral as to be unsatisfying. A better idea might be to wrap these around sushi rice for impromptu maki.

title: Perfect snack when I'm craving salt
review: I keep my pantry stocked with these snacks.  At 60 calories a package, I can eat the whole thing (or even 2 or 3 of them) and not have blown my diet. When a friend told me about them, I thought, "I'm not sure if I like seaweed", but I tried them just so I could say I tried them.  They are so good.  The sesame oil really gives them a good flavor and they satisfy my salt cravings.  My husband loves them too. I can't believe he grabs them for a snack now too.  We're both eating healthier thanks to these snacks.You can find them at the health food stores in the Asian section (Walmart might even have them - I haven't looked in their Asian section).  That way you can try them before ordering a case.I like them so much that I have them ordered on automatic shipment now.  I tried other brands, but Annie Chun's is the best one by far.

title: Salty, Nutritious Snack for the family
review: My kids, elementary and preschool aged, devour each package. They taste like extra thin, salty potato chips.  I absolutely hate the taste of fish and most seafood except shrimp and seaweed used for vegetarian sushi.  This snack does not remind me of fish at all.  I have not noticed any type of offensive smells and I am normally disgusted and lose my appetite around fishy smells.The best part is that these snacks are actually nutritious.  I like that we're getting a 1/3 of Vit A daily needs from them. It's really not that much salt (3% of DV) vs. a lot of processed foods that have much more salt per serving.

title: Im sure its healthy if you can get by the taste.
review: I love wasabi sauce on my sushi and my sister made a great oriental seaweed salad for a hogroast last year that had me thinking this would be a product I would enjoy...  Well once you get past the slight amount of heat from the wasabi (sorry I eat habeneros so yes slight heat) it tasted like burnt rubber.  I brought the box into work from there and it sat for a couple months (within which time a couple people opened and tried 2 of the packages)  After that it made its way to the trash can as nobody wanted to eat it.I really am surprised by some of the reviews on here saying its delicious though...  Maybe I just got a bad pack, or maybe its a case of the shill...  Either way Ill stick with wasabi peas for a quick snack and just wait to get my seaweed fix with my sisters salad or at the local sushi bar piled with the nearly tear bringing wasabi they have there.

title: A little oily, a little funky, and a little light on the salt (for me anyway)...
review: I guess you can never please all the people when it comes to salt, as some people here seem to think there's too much.  Maybe I just like salt, but compared to other seaweed/nori snacks I've had, these are particularly light and not salted enough for me.  That aside, I do like that they come in little wrapped cases to keep me from eating too many in one go.  But at the same time it seems a bit wasteful packaging-wise.  When I opened the individual package, the smell seemed a bit heavy and "off" compared to other seaweed snacks, but I figure seaweed can sometimes be like that and you just have to work around it knowing that it tastes better than it smells.  Also, due to the sesame oil, the inside of the packaging is a bit oily, which in turn gets your fingers a bit oily.  Overall, not bad as seaweed snacks go, but not great.

title: Mediocre for Seaweed Snacking
review: This is one of many varieties of seaweed snacks I've tried in my life. Most of them I get from the Japanese market, which also remain hit and miss. In general, the wasabi dusting overpowers the seaweed and you lose track of the main product.Considering taste as well as value, I rank these are poor if you have local means to pick up some seaweed snacks.  If you aren't near an Asian market, these will do but I might try to find a non-wasabi version.  These are overpowering as well as a tad too salty for my taste.

title: Very tasty but questionable ingredients
review: These are one of the better flavored sea weed snacks, but I'm concerned about a few of the ingredients, especially near the top is canola oil - unless it's organic, it comes from the genetically modified rape seed - there is really no such thing as 'canola' oil and i'm tired of the food manufactures intimating it is a healthy oil. NOT! People need to be educated about this non-food that truly can do you harm over time.also there is modified corn starch, also if not organic than most likely GMO based - Genetically Modified Organism - as is 90% of all corn and soy derived food stuffs in this country -unless stated as organic, youre likely on the losing end. And one more ingredient - maltodextrin -if you are gluten intolerant or sensitive or just want to cut gluten out of your diet, then you don't want this grain derived sweetener. There are other seaweed snacks that have no additives and are not processed with questionable ingredients.

title: Stop deceiving us with misleading nutritional info!
review: The ingredients list sugar and honey yet there is zero grams of sugar in a portion. How can that be?  A portions size is 5 grams and there are 36 portions in a bag so to figure out what a portion is you can either get a scale and weigh them to figure out how many are in 5 grams or  dump out the bag and make 36 piles and then count how many are in a pile This is deliberately deceiving because they don't want us to know what a portion size is.

title: Best Chips EVER
review: These Lundberg Farms brown rice chips are the perfect crunchy, salty snack. I'm very health conscious and don't eat "snack foods" too often. You won't be disappointed.*NOTE on price- These chips are around $2.69/bag but have steadily creeped up in price to well over $3 and change. Shop around. You shouldn't be paying more than $2 and change per bag or you're getting ripped off. And don't forget that many of these sites tack on shipping charges so you'll REALLY be paying too much. I like Vitacost. I've purchased products from them several times and they usually offer free shipping and many good deals. My things always arrive quickly too. Try them.Enjoy your new favorite snack! :)  Be well.

title: I do NOT like healthy, but these are good!
review: I am not a nutritionist, so not going to give you my view on the nutrition of the bars. See the ingredients photo attached for details!What I am sharing my opinion on are they real key factors. How it feels, how it chews, how it taste, how it sits in the stomach and how it poops out. For the record, on a scale of 1-10, 10 being best score, I rate me a 1 when it comes to desire to eat healthy and an 8 at actually eating healthy. In fact, right now I am thinking cheesecake and not a healthy snack bar.PACKAGING – Score 9When it comes to the packaging, I find the package is easy to open, even after sitting in my back pocket before a 10 mile run. The bar is always cleanly in the packaging, not sticking too much too it. I have never had a struggle or frustration taking the food out of the package, an experience you always have with sugar daddy’s (of course, my pre-healthy days only).The package is sealed well and keeps the food tasting fresh.CHEW EFFECT – Score 9I like the texture. Once placed in the mouth, the heavens open up, doves flew out and WAM. Okay, maybe that does not happen, but the texture of the food is solid. It is not too hard or too chewy. When you’re done eating, the food is not crammed between teeth cracks or sticking to the top of the mouth.TASTE – Score 10Awesome. Perfect flavor. Not too sweet.SWALLOW EFFECT – Score 10Good. Repeat and it works great.STOMACH ACCEPTANCE – Score 10Simply awesome. My stomach when it comes to sensitivity is extremely high. If I eat items with too much sugar, my stomach turns. The bars sat well.  They do not sit heavy and they digest well. I never have an issue where gas is leaking out of me (or at least where I can blame it on the bars), so my digestive system pushes it a long well. I am sensitive to gluten, but still no issues.TOILET APPROVED – Score 10This part ended quick, fast and smooth. One big splash finished nature’s course and it was a blessing since lactose issues are normal for me.FAMILY APPROVED – Score 10Wife and Kids love them. Wife loves them because they are easy to store and pull when needed!FINAL COMMENTSGreat product, great flavor. If you are on the fence, try them, you will be impressed.Let me know if the review was helpful!
author: Have Fun, Because It's Too Short!

title: The whole mix is great, but the chocolate makes it worth ordering.
review: I think this is a fantastic price for such a great trail mix.We initially had this on a plane when we were flying home from Cozumel. I thought maybe it was the travel fatigue, and the increasing hunger pangs due to flying through lunch, that made the chocolate in this taste so good at the time. The obvious next logical step was to hunt it down on Amazon, in order to test out the flavor more scientifically in the comfort of my own home.It turns out the chocolate chunks really are that good. Everything else is good too! But the chocolate is the real star here.In conclusion, maybe order it and pick out all the chocolate pieces and then pour the rest into a ziplock bag and be like "look at this trail mix I made!" and your family will be none the wiser and they'll be happy you got them a delicious trail mix, and you'll be happy to have the chocolate pieces hidden away for the days when you need to eat hidden away chocolate.

title: Low in calories and fat but the taste is meh.
review: I bought these Eatsmart Snacks Veggie Crisps as a substitute for regular potato chips which are so high in fat and calories. I like the small portion controlled bags and the chips stay fresher longer bagged in small quantities. The taste is OK but not great. My sister thinks they are awful and my husband says they are bland. Honestly, no one I know likes them but me. And I don't like them like I do other lower fat/calorie chip products..I even like veggie straws better.They're not like my beloved Pringles or Ruffles or even baked chips but they have the crunch, the saltiness, and a decent flavor, They serve the purpose of having a crunchy chip but I don't crave them or choose them over other similar products. I won't buy them often but they do come in handy when I want a salty snack but don't want to indulge in potato chips.

title: ***Allergy Warning****
review: ***Allergy Warning*** While my kids and I do like the taste of these chips the labeling is misleading. If you look on the back of the product under ingredients and allergen information there is nothing to suggest the product contains dairy. On the front of the package in thin letters Dairy is randomly printed under the logo. What is the point of having an allergy section on the package if you aren't listing a regularly recognized food allergy? We checked the chips and thought they were safe and my nephew ate them and had a reaction. I'm incredibly frustrated by this lazy packaging flaw.

title: My new favorite low-carb snack! :-9
review: If you love sushi, you'll also love these seaweed snacks.  They are my new favorite low-carb snack, and perfect for when I feel like munching on something (like when I'm watching a movie).  I have type 1 diabetes, and have to watch my carb intake.  I consider these snacks to be a "free food" as they do not impact my blood sugar, and I do not need to take any insulin when I eat it. The ones I ordered did not have a wasabi taste to them, but a nice, pleasant, lightly roasted sesame taste.  They melt in your mouth and are a healthier alternative to chips, nuts, or popcorn when you need a little snack.I don't have a Trader Joe's where I live, so I'm glad I can order these from Amazon.  I will definitely be ordering more! :-)

title: Delicious, but poor shipping methods
review: Trader Joe's Roasted Seaweed Snacks are delicious.  I crave them the way most people crave potato chips.  They're low in calories (60 calories for the entire package) and contain beneficial minerals that you might not get elsewhere, so you can eat a ton of them without feeling guilty.  It's an excellent product.The problem was that these were shipped in a bag, not a box.  This would be fine if the plastic box inside the wrapping were rigid, but it's not.  Every box was flattened at some point during shipping.  Seaweed snacks don't really bend without breaking.  Everything was broken into little shards that drifted around the inside of the package during shipping, so when I went to open one of the packages, the seaweed on the outside of its container got all over the place.  Since these are made with oil, it's very hard to get little bits off of a surface.  Eating them without making a mess was equally difficult.  You'd think for $5 shipping the sellers would at least make sure the product made it to the buyer in one piece.  I wish they had taken the care to use a box rather than a bag.  What I really wish was that I'd just made the trip to Trader Joe's and bought them there.  I'm very disappointed.
author: Caroline

title: Satisfying Salty Sea Snack
review: This salty, savory gem is so satisfying.  Packaged in an airtight container, it is as fresh and crisp as the moment it was packed at the factory.  Each package has only 60 calories--and that's for two servings!  The seaweed comes in thin, rectangular sheets of a beautiful shade of green.  As you take a bite, the crisp sheet reminds you of biting into a potato chip or popcorn--crunch and a bit of salt.  Once on your tongue, it begins to dissolve, giving you a more gelatinous texture.  If you enjoy Japanese foods such as sushi, this is for you.What a great, low calorie alternative to take to the movies.  Or, to lunch, to eat at your desk, in the car, at sports events, on the plane.  Easy to handle, small, crunchy, salty, chewy.  M-m-m, just plain yummy.
author: Sharon Beverly

title: Not A Healthy Snack
review: I love roasted seaweed snacks. I have purchased these directly from a Trader Joe's store. This brand is on the bland and flimsy side of the seaweed snack spectrum, but they are tasty enough. The upside of seaweed snacks for me is the iodine content. If you've never tried seaweed snacks before, they may be an acquired taste. The downside is that they are made with canola oil which is unhealthy because it inhibits enzyme function among other effects. There are other brands which are canola-free. Had these been canola-free, I could only wish that the people who dumped theirs in the trash would have sent them my way. Based on that fact that there are seaweed snacks with healthier ingredients, I won't be buying these again. In fact, I will try making them at home with a recipe found in my search for canola-free snacks. If you do eat these, you may experience digestive upsets if you consume more than a few at a time. I don't know if it's because of the canola oil or if it's seaweed-related, but this seems to be a common side effect.

review: At first I gave this a low-rating, since I thought it contributed to my kid's acne.  After 1 year of using this, I upgrade to 5-stars. This product also has 8% vitamin A (helps with skin & thyroid), plus 20% vitamin C, and 2% iron.  One pack has only 30 calories, and only 99 cents at Trader's Joe.I notice that I nap easier when I snack on this for breakfast.  I appreciate this product for is low-cost, low-calories, and how it helps my teenager daughter with her hypothyroid .. her skin is clear, despite having one pack per day.  Seaweed has minerals:  iodine, potassium, magnesium, calcium and iron.

title: Surprisingly...Awesome!
review: I'm no vegetarian, and am certainly not a "granola girl," yet I find these so amazingly tasty! There's just a moderately salty crunch at first, and then they basically "melt in your mouth." The flavor is exactly like the seaweed wrapped around sushi rolls; no "fishy" taste.Like other reviewers, I initially decided to try these because (1) they're crazy-low in calories, and (2) I'd heard about how healthy seaweed is. So glad I did! These - remarkably - satisfy my husband's salty-crunchy cravings, so we don't buy any potato chips/tortilla chips/pretzels/popcorn anymore!I really wanted to dock a star for (1) wanting to eat more than are in each package (aka: the package is too small), and (2) because they're pretty pricey compared to other salty-crunchy snacks. But, I just couldn't do it. They are too darn delicious! I would buy these in bulk at Sam's Club if I could!Side note: I haven't done any research on the health benefits of dried v. fresh seaweed. I suspect that fresh has many more vitamins/nutrients, but that's purely my own speculation. If anyone has any info on this...please comment on my review so I can take a look. Thanks!

title: Addictive and delicious!
review: This review is going to sound very different from a normal one.First off, I would like to point out that yes, I gave it four stars on purpose.  Please keep that in mind and read this very thoroughly.I hate these snacks.  I hate them because they are so insanely addictive, I find it nearly impossible to "just have one."  Invariably, I end up consuming the entire package grinning like a giddy schoolchild.  Even if I put them away, I will inevitably find myself searching the package out, just so I can have one more.. and then again, and again, until the package is finally empty, and then I am sad.I hate them because of their fun, paper-thin texture, which makes it seem like you've some piece of unique candy, then it turns out to be a delicious, slightly salty, somewhat chewy snack which makes your brain scream 'Oooh, yay, SUSHI!' only for it to suddenly turn nutty in a twist which makes me want to have just one more to experience that fun crinkle of the sheets (for they are super-thin sheets of dried, roasted seaweed), the YAY of incoming sushi, that slightly chewy transformation, and then they dissolve into almost nothingness, leaving you reaching for another one.I hate them because the pack lasts about 45 minutes.  An hour and a half, if I'm demonstrating exceptionally strong willpower for the day.  Possibly longer if I can manage to convince someone *else* to hide them from me.I hate them because said pack gives me 40% of my Vitamin C for the day in less than half an ounce of actual dried seaweed.  And something that tastes so very delicious isn't supposed to be that healthy.  Bacon doesn't give vitamin C.  These snacks do.  That's confusing.  Snacks are supposed to be guilty pleasures, not delightful dietary supplements.I hate them because the only physical store that carries them in my area is Trader Joe's, and I always end up opening the pack after they are closed.  So when the package is empty and I am sad, I must wait until morning to "get my fix" again.I hate them because I ate an entire package while writing this review.  And now it is gone.  And now I am sad.  Thankfully, though, I can get them here and have them delivered to my door.  I might have to order a few of the six packs, though, to last me until the next order I place can arrive.  I'm working out a rationing calendar that I probably won't stick to for more than an hour.And finally, I hate that I don't hate these at all, but am hopelessly and utterly addicted to them.  Seaweed Anonymous, thou art my name.
author: Amazon Customer

title: It tastes like bay water.
review: I received a package of Trader Joe's Roasted Seaweed Snack for my 23rd birthday. Growing up deeply entrenched in Asian cuisine, I knew before trying it that it was more than likely not going to be to my tastes. If you like products such as grass jelly or sushi, or anything that is pungent and tastes like plant material without being om nom nom delicious, this is for you.This product is not recommended for small children. There's not enough sugar in it.This product is also not recommended for vegans and seliacs. While it is gluten free and animal-product free, you can do something better for yourselves by finding an alternative snack without the bay water flavor.This product is not recommended for people with heart disease or who are at risk for developing heart disease. It's a high sodium choice.This product is not recommended for alcoholics. You'll start drinking again.This product is not recommended for cigarette smokers. Save your money for your cancer sticks.This product IS recommended for users of Mountain Dew, grass or ai ju jelly, pickled radish, bean thread, sushi, menudo, mole sauce, adobo sauce, specialty bell peppers, bouncy balls, pencil and pen erasers, rubber soles, rubber in general, motor oil, gasoline/petrol, radioactive isotopes, unidentified rare earth metals, tapeworms, Buffalo Bills fans, fruit cake, Hostess snacks, corn, rat, and/or chicken snakes, parents of teenagers (for use as a punishment agent on those late night sneak outs), water bottles, organic milk, Tuscan Whole Milk, Three Wolf Moon shirts, wolf shirts in general, Twilight readers, and insomniacs.The flavor matches wonderfully with a fresh whole rabbit, such as the one listed on this site.I would rate it higher than two stars in the regards that it's a wonderful seaweed product. However, I don't like it. That's the definition of two stars.
author: Proofs and Truths

title: Rank tasting, stale chips
review: When I have purchased Terra sea salt vegetable chips from the local stores, they have always tasted great, but this online purchase left me with a bad taste in my mouth, (no pun intended). Firstly, the 24 pack of chips arrived with an  eight day expiration date!! On past performance, I really like these chips, but I don't think we'd be eating 24 bags in a little more than a week! Secondly, EVERY BAG TASTED BAD! Chips tasted stale, were chewy and indigestable, and frankly had a rank "off"  taste. NONE of the bags we opened were crispy. Thirdly, I sent them back to Amazon, and received a replacement box of Terra Chips. These chips do taste marginally better,  and are within sell-by date, but for some reason do not have the fresh taste we are used to experiencing from  Terra Chips purchased from our local grocery store. The batch tastes stale and so we threw them out as it is too much hassle to go through the hassle of having to have them replaced AGAIN, Won't be purchasing again..

review: I have been eating and enjoying these chips for over 15 years.  Sometimes, I would get a bag of stale chips that tasted like cardboard, but this would occur infrequently.  Over the last year, the chip quality started to change radically with entire batches of 24 bags of chips being stale or impossible to eat because they were too hard. title: Wise choice for people who need to count on calories
review:
So far the best potato chip I ever had. It's crispy yet without traditional oil frying. It has incredibly low calories compared to regular potato chips which I like. When you think about snack chips available in the market, you can't really find something that is "healthier choice" but Terra Chips give you variety option of baked chip without the trans fats, real vegetables, with no sodium option. It has over 25 different varieties available.Nice thing about this chips are it comes with smaller package which is about 28 grams while other regular brand chips come with 50 grams. I have tried original recipe, sweet potatoes, taro, and my favorite blue potatoes. Unlike real veggies, it will come with all the calories and fat of a regular chip but with healthier version. It has a line of no-added salt version which is good to manage their sodium level.Packaging was superior, all of my 24 chips come in one box without scattered pieces. I can't wait to try different varieties when they have more promotional sale.Tip: Price changes constantly, just monitor the price to grab a best deal.

TERRA Blues, Sea Salt, 1 Ounce (Pack of 24)

title: Need to find them in larger sizes
review: Had these on JetBlue a couple of times and was hooked. I looked at several health food stores for them and came up empty-handed, although they had Terra brand chips.  I wonder why this flavor are so hard to find.  The small bags may be fine as a free snack on an airplane, but it felt wasteful as a snack at home.  All the little bags.  One is never enough and you reach for another. And another.  I felt like I was paying more for air than for chips.  The chips were generally delicious, but some bags had chips that seemed stale and more tough than what I had on JetBlue.  But next time I'm hunting for these chips, I will want to find them in regular size bags.

title: FAKE PRODUCT!!!!!
review: I love Kirkland roasted sea weed from Costco. They are crispy with a slight salty taste. I used to eat one or two servings everyday. But recently Costco no longer carry them anymore. So I found them on Amazon and ordered one bag with 8 packs in it. What a fake! The bag wrapping is apparently hand-made. The aluminum wrapping looks genuine. But the plastic containers in it are all deformed. The seaweeds are stale and tasteless. Oh, did I mention the price is twice I paid at Costco warehouse? I am positive this is a fraudulent product. Costco and Amazon  needs to investigate this crime! I threw away the rest of it for safety reasons.

title: Bought It At Costco When In Stock & 50 Flakes Not 5 Flakes & Only $9.88.
review: This a great Product that comes full Packaged Protecting the 50 Roasted Flakes per 10 Packages that are also wrapped in 1 Bundle.  Perfect to replace Potato Chips as snake, put on Fish Sandwiches, Shrimp Salads, Pizza and any Fish Sui-chi Dish making all crunchy when biting into them. Adds great flavor as well.  Lately, it has been hit or miss at Costco, sometimes have them, then sold out. Amazon deliveries are just great as well if they will match the price and quantity.  I know the seaweed is sold in different flavors but i can't tell the difference just a great ocean taste. Highly recommend the product and is a big hit at parties or serving with other dishes for guests. One is wary at first look and bite but try a few and you won't by Potatoes Chips for a long time.  Total fat 1.5 Grams with 1 Gram of Protein per 20 Flakes servings. Zero Saturated or Trans Fats, Carbs, or Sugars either. Does come with 40 mg salt but high in Iron and Potassium and good for Thyroid as some studies have shown on Seaweed Ingredients, Vitamins and Benefits.
author: J. Janos

title: The crackers have a great taste, but.....
review: Update 7/26/20 - After continued shipping problems with the crackers always arriving as mostly crumbs and several phone calls to Amazon complaining about it, we have decided to stop ordering this product. Amazon now sells a similar cracker that's just as tasty but ships in a solid plastic container which provides much better protection than the mylar bag of this cracker. I knocked a star off my original review as we are still dealing with this TWO YEARS LATER. It's an unfortunate situation because these are otherwise very delicious crackers that are marred and tainted only by its packaging and shipping practices.We order these in the flexible mylar bag. The crackers have a great taste and are a favorite of our family. Unfortunately, we always receive these with nearly half of the crackers crushed because they are shipped in a soft, flexible envelope packaging. Order at your own risk.

title: FINALLY! SOME GOOD ARARE
review: I didn't start out looking for these, but was real glad I did!  I've enjoyed these crackers since I was a kid.  I had a neighbor who was Japanese and introduced me to a lot of fun snacks.  These can be hard to find, depending on where you live, at least good ones.  So after looking at some of the offerings and the prices on Amazon I settled on giving these and the Asia Trans Co. a try.These have wonderful deep soy sauce flavor and color.  And many others I've tried just pale in comparison, seriously, they're a very light color or actually white and there's very little taste.Beware - This particular brand of arare  contain MSG.  So those of you who freak out about this ingredient or are sensitive to it - stay away.The bag came full to the brim in its own resealable bag. The bag itself is pretty thick and I hope the seal is tight enough to keep them fresh.  Nothing worse than getting some of these and the next day or two and they're stale.  In comparing these to the Asia Trans brand, I find these to have a better flavor; that's probably the addition on the msg, but I'll take it.The two bags came in a single box, without  paper or plastic bubble packs so they wouldn't bang around and break into cracker dust.  So I was surprised to find that they're mostly intact.  I poured some in a bowl, tried to get pieces from the bottom as well.  You can see that there are not a lot of broken pieces despite there not being any padding. I also put some on the paper with a bottle cap to show scale, since these are not very large.  I also included a picture of the expiration date, a little over eight months from now.Overall, I'm very satisfied with these and would buy them again.  I'm not sure I'd share them just yet, maybe just direct them to Amazon so they can get their own pack.
author: Raevyn77

title: Delicious, delicious, delicious
review: These taste great!  I grew up eating arare (rice crackers) so I consider myself somewhat of a rice cracker snob.  I would always want the pieces that were the darkest, they were either toasted the most or had the most soy sauce on them, either way they had the best flavor.  If you are the kind of person that likes the browned bits of rice that sits in the bottom of your rice cooker then you know what I mean.  These crackers are nice and dark, full of flavor and very crispy.  So many of the rice crackers you see in stores today are pale and don't look too appetizing.  I was somewhat cautious about ordering these rice crackers since they were made in Taiwan and in my opinion the best ones come from Japan.  However these are absolutely delicious. I read that some people have had issues with broken pieces (NOT ME) or the price (about $12.00 per pound).  An 8 ounce package of rice crackers locally sells for $5.00-5.50, That's $10-11 per pound for much inferior rice crackers.  These are not cheap but well worth the price.  I won't be buying them every week, but maybe once a month????
author: GMak

title: My go to brand for mochi crunch
review: This is one of the best mochi crunch brand there is.  I've tried many different brands and as far as the taste goes.  This is one of the best.  For one, it doesn't taste too salty like some other arare.  I also like the convenience of having to purchase this myself with free prime shipping (with membership).  The fact that I don't have to bother my friends or relatives there.  Just get this myself.  It's an expensive product, but, 2 lbs, 6 oz, that's alot of mochi crunch in one bottle.  I don't know of any other company that does that.  I think is because they have such a great product that people are willing to pay for a full bottle of arare.  Besides the point, I could continue to make my furikake mochi crunch butter popcorn (similar to hurricane popcorn).  Just as tasty but, better flavor.

title: TOTALLY Unacceptable
review: First off, let me say I have in the past always ordered the Aloha brand mix and been extremely satisfied. However when I saw this product with a greater quantity for approximately the same price, I decided to chance it. However when I poured out some mix in a bowl, I was shocked to see that at least the third if not more of all of the small pieces we're broken. See my photo. In fact when I looked closely I saw that there were pieces that were plain and others that had seaweed in them. It was obvious to me that these are what was swept up from several different production lines, not the high-quality product that I expected.Although I did eventually consume the whole bag, it was irritating because the number of broken pieces got larger and larger till the very bottom where everything was small and crushed.Save your money and aggravation. Buy the Aloha brand instead.

title: So Good!
review: I grew up on Umeya rice crackers- when I was a kid we'd always get the jumbo bags of them from the Umeya store in downtown Los Angeles. Since Umeya is no more, I started looking for a good alternative. The best tasting and best deal I've found is the Tomoe Brand Hawaiian Mix Arare in the jumbo bag. These have really good flavor and the 38 oz bag lasts for a while. One big plus is they don't use those chemical food coloring dyes to make their Arare like a lot of the other companies do. My only regret is not finding these sooner. Anyway buy a bag- you won't regret it!

title: Delicious but Must Be Shared
review: These Golden Duck Gourmet Salted Egg Yolk Fish Skin Crisps Chips were undeniably delicious. Crispy, a little spicy, and they just melt in your mouth. My wife, who is incredibly picky when it comes to chips, found these to be fragrant and crispy ( as the name suggests) and actually requested that we ordered more in the future, to my surprise!I do want to note that given that these are pretty oily, so eating too much will definitely lead to a bit of throat uncomfortableness. It's really a matter of self-control when making sure that you don't eat all the crisps in one sitting. With some tea or some water, I think that these chips are much easier to digest, and you'll definitely thank me later for the tip. If only they sold these chips in my hometown, I'd be purchasing them monthly for the whole family to enjoy! For the price that you pay, it is also a little expensive; most chip bags do have quite a bit of air though. It is undeniable, however, that the bags are fresh, and the fish used is fresh and results in chips that are fare from stale.
author: Kc T.

title: ... to have a real taste for the sea to love this.
review: You have to have a real taste for the sea to love this...Seaweed is good for the iodine it provides, helps move your bowls and over all, is good for your health.  I eat it directly from the pack, but it's excellent with smoked salmon and light cream cheese spread on it or in Asian style soups....Yum!  The one bad thing is it will turn your breath fouler than anything...it's indescribable, so be sure to brush your teeth, gums and tongue (especially the back of your tongue)...and then repeat it again...SERIOUSLY, you do not want to talk closely with anyone after eating this or you will forever leave a bad impression!

title: Not the first brand i've tried, and not bad at all...  :)
review: This is now the second brand of seaweed snacks that i've tried.I had held onto an empty package of "Sea Veggies[tm]" that i purchased from a local Kroger's store for *months*, telling myself if i ever get to that Kroger's again i'll need to buy more of these 'cause they're a great snack...  Eventually i went online and that particular brand seemed too expensive in bulk so i went with this Trader Joe's version.  Honestly, i can't tell them apart (though admittedly it's best a few months or more since i had that competing brand).When i finish the last of these i'll move on to another brand and review those, too.  ^_^

title: Very Good, but...
review: Very Good, but...if you do not like green things, (dark green veggies, chlorella) or flavors from the ocean, fish of any kind (sushi or nori)you will most likely not like this.I like it and feel I will like it more as I get more accustomed to it. title: My new favorite low-carb snack! :-9
review: If you love sushi, you'll also love these seaweed snacks.  They are my new favorite low-carb snack, and perfect for when I feel like munching on something (like when I'm watching a movie).  I have type 1 diabetes, and have to watch my carb intake.  I consider these snacks to be a "free food" as they do not impact my blood sugar, and I do not need to take any insulin when I eat it. The ones I ordered did not have a wasabi taste to them, but a nice, pleasant, lightly roasted sesame taste.  They melt in your mouth and are a healthier alternative to chips, nuts, or popcorn when you need a little snack.I don't have a Trader Joe's where I live, so I'm glad I can order these from Amazon.  I will definitely be ordering more! :-)
